Review Rational catalyst design and interface engineering for electrochemical CO2 reduction to high-valued alcohols Lingxi Zhou a Ruitao Lv a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of New Ceramics and Fine Processing, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China State Key Laboratory of New Ceramics and Fine Processing School of Materials Science and Engineering Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China State Key Laboratory of New Ceramics and Fine Processing, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China b Key Laboratory of Advanced Materials (MOE), School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China Key Laboratory of Advanced Materials (MOE) School of Materials Science and Engineering Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China Key Laboratory of Advanced Materials (MOE), School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Strategies for boosting the electrochemical CO2 reduction to alcohol products are summarized based on the state-of-the-art researches on the catalyst design and interface engineering. Electrochemical CO2 reduction (eCO2RR) is an emerging strategy to address the global carbon balance issues and fulfill the carbon-neutral goal through converting CO2 to value-added chemicals/fuels driven by renewable energy sources. The production of highly reduced carbon compounds beyond CO and formate, especially oxygenate alcohol products with high energy densities and large global market capacities, is particularly desirable for practical applications. However, the building of alcohol-selective eCO2RR electrocatalysis systems to overcome the high overpotential and poor durability remains a big challenge. Recently, diverse strategies have been developed for rational catalyst design towards alcohol productions from eCO2RR on the basis of the corresponding reaction mechanisms. In this review article, we firstly highlight recent advances in fundamental understanding of mechanisms in three electrochemical CO2-alcohol reaction pathways. Then, the design strategies focused on catalyst and interface design are summarized for building alcohol-selective eCO2RR electrocatalysis systems. The advanced characterization techniques are also discussed to provide more insights into eCO2RR-to-alcohols processes. Finally, the remaining challenges and perspectives for promoting eCO2RR to alcohols are proposed. Keywords Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction Alcohols Electrocatalysis Selectivity 1 Introduction Excessive consumption of fossil fuels has severely interfered the balance of natural carbon cycle due to the large amounts of anthropogenic CO2 emissions, leading to the global warming and energy crisis problems [1–3]. To address such issues, considerable efforts have been exerted to transforming CO2 to valuable fuels and/or chemicals. A number of technologies including photochemical, thermochemical, biochemical and electrocatalytic method have been developed for converting CO2 to the desired products [4–7]. Notably, electrocatalytic method driven by renewable and clean electricity energy has attracted enormous interest in virtue of its relatively high efficiency and near-zero emission. In addition, this method conducted at ambient conditions with an aqueous solution as electrolyte is considered as a sustainable process since the engaged electrons and protons for reactions originate from the abundant and renewable water [8]. However, due to the complicated multiple electron and proton-transfer kinetics for the electrochemical CO2 reduction (eCO2RR), various kinds of products (e.g., CO, CH4, HCOOH, CH3OH, C2H5OH, CH3COOH) have been achieved [9,10]. Among them, the direct conversion of CO2 to alcohols using electrochemical method demonstrates merits as below: (1) the liquid products of alcohols can be facilely stored and transported compared with the gas products which require complicated processes for the compressing and sealing; (2) the isolation of alcohols from electrolyte is more convenient compared with the vented gas products which are always composed of multiple mixed gases, such as H2 and unreacted CO2, whereas the purifications of such gas products require additional complicated and costly procedures; (3) the generated alcohols can be directly applied in power-supply systems (e.g., fuel cells) to produce electricity which hold large global market capacities, allowing the creation of a carbon-neutral cycle with economic benefit in a sustainable way. So far, the eCO2RR systems to selectively produce CO and HCOOH have been widely studied and the design of electrocatalysts has made great progress [11–17]. However, alcohol production through eCO2RR process still suffers from high overpotential, low Faradaic efficiency (FE) and low yield rate. Although the reactions of eCO2RR to methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH) and propanol (PrOH) are thermodynamically feasible, the inert nature of CO2 molecule and multiple electron and proton transfers make the overall reaction kinetically sluggish. Thus, the applied cell potential is larger than thermodynamic potential because both the anode oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and cathode CO2RR require large overpotentials. In addition, the equilibrium potential of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is similar to that of CO2RR, thus HER is an inevitable competing reaction [18]. Apart from these high energy barriers of eCO2RR, the selective formation of alcohol products faces more challenges due to the thermodynamically more favorable hydrocarbon (i.e., CH4, C2H4) pathways. Since the multielectron participation process is very sensitive to the intrinsic properties of catalytic materials and electrolyte components, rational design of efficient catalysis systems for eCO2RR to alcohols with both high selectivity and high FE as well as low overpotential are highly desirable. With regard to the recent progress in eCO2RR to produce alcohols, several review articles have been published, which mainly focused on the catalyst design for production of MeOH from eCO2RR [19–23]. Recently, great achievements have been made in the building of electrolysis systems for eCO2RR towards multi-carbon alcohols by rational catalyst and interface engineering. In order to provide guidelines for further research, it is crucial to summarize the state-of-the-art progresses of electrolysis systems for alcohol productions from eCO2RR. In this review article, we first discuss the mechanism toward alcohol products as the fundamental principles to catalysis systems design. Then the innovative strategies based on catalyst and interface are introduced focusing on active site: activating the intrinsic reactivity of each catalytic site via component regulation; maximum its ultilization by regulating the size, number and atomic arrangement via structure engineering and ensuring its fully accessiblily in the actual electrolysis process via microenvironment modulation, as shown in Scheme 1 and Table 1 . Besides, the mechanism and descriptors for catalyst design for eCO2RR to C1 and C2+ alcohol products are summerized in Table 2 . Accordingly, the advanced eCO2RR-to-alcohols catalysts were listed in Table 3 . We also discuss the advanced characterization techniques to provide more insights into eCO2RR-to-alcohols processes. On this basis, the remaining challenges and perspectives for eCO2RR to alcohols are proposed. 2 Mechanism of eCO2RR to alcohol products Revealing the reaction mechanism through theoretical and experimental methods is quite important for guiding the design and synthesis of efficient catalysts [24]. Thus, the investigation on mechanism for eCO2RR to alcohols is of significant importance for rational design and synthesis of electrocatalysts with improved catalytic efficiency. Generally, the product selectivity for eCO2RR depends on the capability of a catalyst to stabilize different reaction intermediates on the catalyst surface during the electrochemical process. Cu-based materials have been widely investigated as model catalysts to study the possible reaction pathways for appreciable alcohol generations via eCO2RR [25–28]. The products of eCO2RR usually depend on the electron transfer amount. Regarding the specific reaction pathways for eCO2RR, the pre-absorbed CO2 molecule firstly reacts with electrons and protons on the catalyst surface, followed by the desorption of generated products (Fig. 1 a). Specifically, CO2 may bind to the electrode surface via the C or the O (resulting in a single adsorption intermediate, *COOH, or a bidentate *OCHO intermediate, respectively) [26]. It is suggested that *COOH is more likely the first intermediate for CO formation, and *OCHO is more likely the intermediate for formic acid production. Generally, post-transition metals such as Pb and Sn prefer to bind CO2 via O and are favorable for *OCHO and selective towards formic acid, whereas transition-metal electrodes prefer to bind via C [26,27]. As the alcohols are deep reduction products beyond CO, the adsorbed *CO is an essential intermediate for producing alcohols. Metals with weak *CO binding energy (i.e., Au, Ag) and strong capability of binding with *COOH facilitate the formation of CO as the main product [28]; While metals with strong *CO binding energy (i.e., Ni, Pt) can become poisoned. Attributing to the optimal binding strength of *CO species, Cu-based electrocatalysts can catalyze eCO2RR to C1 to C3 alcohols [25,27,29]. For the C1 alcohol MeOH productioin, the generated *CO can be protonated to form absorbed *COH or *CHO, which is considered as the rate-determine step (RDS). Afterwards, *COH or *CHO undergoes several proton-electroncoupled transfer (PECT) steps to produce *OCH3 species. The further hydrogenation of *OCH3 decides the selectivity between MeOH and methane which is considered as the selective-determine intermediate (SDI) [30,31]. While the possible reaction routes including electrochemical and chemical steps for synthesizing C2 alcohol products are quite complicated. According to the “carbene” pathway, CO insertion in a Fischer-Tropsch-like step has been considered as the potential route to EtOH [32]. Alternatively, the dimerization of *CO with an electron transfer can generate the critical intermediate of *C2O2 − and followed by protonating to *CH2–CHO (Fig. 1b) [29,33,34]. As the subsequent reduction pathway of *CH2–CHO can be divided either to ethylene or C2+ alcohols, *CH2–CHO is regarded as the SDI for C2+ alcohols production. While Sargent’s group proposed that *HOCCH is the SDI from which branches the ethylene pathway (*CCH) and the EtOH pathway (HOCHCH*) [35,36]. Note that the eCO2RR to produce C3 alcohol still remains a grand challenge since only few studies have successfully obtained C3 alcohols [37]. It was proposed that the intermolecular C–C coupling of adsorbed C2 and C1 intermediates and subsequently proton/electron transfers resulted in the formation of propionaldehyde, which could be further hydrogenated to PrOH (Fig. 1c) [32,38]. In brief summary, the C1-C3 alcohols are the deep reduction products of eCO2RR beyond CO with the carbons in the same deeply reduced state [40,41]. Therefore, an optimal *CO binding strength is ideal for alcohols production. HER and eCO2RR-to-hydrocarbons are the common competing reactions for eCO2RR-to-alcohols, therefore, a relatively weak *H adsorption on active site is desired [41]. For eCO2RR to C1 products, the formation of CH4 is thermodynamically more favorable than that of CH3OH which makes the eCO2RR-to-MeOH considerably inaccessible as compared to other hydrocarbons or alcohols. A weaker interaction between O and the surface would preferentially produce MeOH by facilitating the desorption of a whole *OCH3 group from the surface, while a strong interaction between O and the surface would provide more chances to break the O–CH3 bond, producing CH4 as a main product [40]. For the reaction to generate C2+ chemicals, ethylene is formed through the cleavage of the remaining C–O bond and desorbed, leaving an adsorbed oxygen atom [41]. Therefore, a relatively weak O binding and strong C–O bond prevented from hydrogenation would preferentially produce C2+ alcohols. 3 Rational catalyst design for eCO2RR-to-alcohols 3.1 Component regulation As the intrinsic properties of elements determine the adsorption behavior of active sites for key intermediates, component regulation is an efficient strategy to design catalysts, thus significantly affecting the reaction pathways. The activity and variability of a single active site are limited. Introducing other metal and non-metal elements to form alloys and compounds to construct multiple active sites can effectively regulate the reaction activity and product distribution in eCO2RR (Fig. 2 ). In order to systematically evaluate the binding ability of metals to O-bound reaction intermediates from a macro perspective, descriptors are also designed for eCO2RR: H affinity and O affinity. It has been found that the metal O and H affinities play important roles in a catalyst’s activity and selectivity by influencing the strength of M–O/M–H bonds and therefore the binding energy of specific reaction intermediates (i.e., *CHO, *CH2O and * CH3O for alcohols) on their surface [40]. Vasileff et al. classified the metals into four main groups based on their H and O affinity relative to that of Cu as the benchmark metal (Fig. 3 a) [40]. Low or high binding energy with H and O is not conducive to the selective formation of alcohols. As the active site with relatively weak H and O binding is favorable for alcohols production based on the above analysis, metals in group I (Ag, Au, Zn, etc.) are generally considered as active element for eCO2RR-to-alcohols. While the metals of the group III and IV are not generally conducive to the formation of alcohols, as their strong H binding favors the generation of hydrogen and hydrocarbon products (Fig. 3b and c). It can also be seen from the density functional theory (DFT) calculation results that Pt, Ni and Pd in group III and IV are located below the diagonal, which are conducive to the competitive reaction of hydrocarbon generation, thus inhibiting the alcohol pathway (Fig. 3d). The active metal elements for the formation of alcohol products are mainly concentrated on Cu and the group I metals, which are located above the diagonal. 3.1.1 Compositing (Mono-metal sites) Cu is the only metal that can efficiently produce C1-C3 alcohol products with acceptable activity and efficiency during the eCO2RR [40,41]. Therefore, this section mainly summarizes the strategies for preparing eCO2RR-to-alcohol electrocatalysts with mono-Cu as active site. It should be clear that ‘component’ and ‘active site’ are not the same concept, single component Cu can also provide multiple sites to catalyze the formation of C2+ alcohol products [42–45]. Since alcohols are the deep reduction products beyond CO, the common purpose for obtaining efficient CO2-to-alcohol electrocatalysts is to strengthen the binding of *CO on each active site [40,41]. For the selective production of MeOH, it is necessary to promote the hydrogenation of *CO; while for the synthesis of C2+ alcohols, promoting the dimer of *CO and inhibit the formation of C2H4 are critical [34,38]. OD-Cu. Compared with pure copper, it was surprised to find that the yield of MeOH boosted on the Cu2O fabricated by Frese in 1990s [46]. Since then oxide derived Cu (OD-Cu) has been widely used in the synthesis of alcohol products [42,47–53]. They believe that Cu(I) and at least a monolayer of oxygen are conducive to the formation of MeOH, but the mechanism was not clear. This pioneering work provided important conclusions that the valence state and chemical environment of Cu would have a great impact on the product distributions of eCO2RR. On this basis, numerous theoretical and experimental studies have been proposed to promote the activity and selectivity of eCO2RR towards alcohol production by manipulating the valence and chemical environment of mono-Cu sites [42,43,52,54–56]. By analyzing the electronic structures of Cu2O with variable intermediates, Mikosch’s and Jiang’s group theoretically revealed the origin of higher activity of OD-Cu than Cu metal in the eCO2RR-to-MeOH process [49,52]. They demonstrated that the adsorption of CO2 on OD-Cu was enhanced by the coordinatively unsaturated Cu centers on the Cu2O surface, which facilitated the formation of surface carbonate with the aid of O. Experimental results also indicated MeOH yields were dynamic and OD-Cu are reduced to metallic Cu in a simultaneous process at the potentials required for CO2 reduction [48]. In contrast with Cu electrodes, where CH4 is the preferred reduction product, Cu(I) species may improve the stability of *CO and lattice O atoms can stabilize *H to hydrogenate the O atom of *OCH3 intermediate, thus alter selectivity towards MeOH [49,52]. However, the insufficient stability of Cu2O under reductive conditions led to continuously diminished MeOH yield [51]. While more experimental and computational work is needed, these results suggest Cu(I) species and lattice O play critical roles in selectivity towards MeOH and the stability of OD-Cu may be a key factor for maintaining catalytic activity in other alcohol generation reactions. Furthermore, OD-Cu catalysts were active for eCO2RR-to-C2+ alcohols. Crumlin’s and Ager’s group found that the the subsurface O would generate a mix of Cu(I) and Cu(0) on the surface [50,51]. These could then work with adsorbed H2O and aid in CO2 activation by forming chemisorbed CO2. It was experimentally found that Cu(I) and Cu(0) regions could act synergistically to promote *CO dimerization, thereby boosting selectivity towards C2+ alcohols [51]. Shang et al. reported the facile construction of core-shell Cu@Cu2O through the oxidation of as-prepared Cu nanorods at room temperature, leading to the generation of abundant Cu(I)/Cu(0) interface [57]. The high stability of Cu(I) species in the eCO2RR process enabled the co-existence of dual active sites of Cu(I) and Cu(0) in Cu@Cu2O, facilitating the generation of both positively and negatively charged carbon atoms and thereby the dimerization of C–C bond toward C2 products. Thus, a selectivity of 50% for ethylene and EtOH could be achieved from eCO2RR at −1.0 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)). Most recently, Ting et al. detected for the first time C4 alcohol 1-butanol from eCO2RR on CuO-derived Cu electrodes, in which oxidized metal species benefited the C–C coupling step between two acetaldehyde molecules, while the Cu surface promoted the subsequent dehydration step to crotonaldehyde [53]. Therefore, the mixed valence state of Cu and lattice/subsurface O in oxides play important roles in regulating the adsorption energy of *CO. Obtaining stable OD-Cu with tunable compositions to control the subsequent reduction behavior of *CO is highly desirable but remains a challenge for the selective production of specific alcohols. Cu-based chalcogenides. S and Se of the same family as O have similar electronic structures, which have also been introduced to modify mono-Cu active sites. Copper selenides and copper sulfides have structure stability, multiple oxidation states and high electrical conductivity, which can deliver great electrochemical properties [54,58]. It was found that chalcogenide atoms at the edges played an essential role in adjusting the chemical environment of metal sites to optimize the binding energies of the intermediates [59]. Han’s group firstly applied copper selenide as excellent electrocatalyst for eCO2RR to MeOH with FEMeOH of up to 77.6% at a record high current density of 41.5 mA cm−2 under a low overpotential of 285 mV [58]. Recently, Sargent’s group introduced S into Cu surfaces to tune the energetics of intermediate binding [54]. The as-synthesized core-shell electrocatalysts with Cu surface shell and Cu2S core modify the C2 reaction pathway, shifting selectivity away from ethylene and towards multi-carbon alcohols (PrOH and EtOH). Therefore, when Cu is served as mono-M active center, the mixed valence state of Cu can be obtained by introducing O and other non-metallic elements to form compounds, changing the chemical environment of the metal center, so as to improve its adsorption behavior on key intermediates to obtain alcohol products. Other metal composites with mono-metal site. In addition to Cu, very rare reports show that Ru, Pd and Fe could also be applied as mono-M active centers to drive the formation of alcohol products in the eCO2RR process, and elements such as P could also be used to regulate the chemical environment of active centers [60,61]. For example, Sun’s group reported the catalytic efficiency of FeP nanoarray on Ti mesh as electrocatalysts for eCO2RR with high FEs of 80.2% and 14.1% for MeOH and EtOH at −0.20 V vs. RHE, respectively [62]. They then reported the highly selective production of alcohols from eCO2RR using Fe2P2S6 nanosheet as an effective electrocatalyst [63]. The DFT calculation results disclosed that the chemical environment of Fe atom was optimized by S and P, which can serve as a favorable active site for eCO2RR and thermodynamically favored process of MeOH production. It was the uncontrollability of the continuous reduction and dimer behavior after *CO adsorption that leads to the formation of this mixed alcohol products. The regulation of mono-M site is limited, but its basic model is closest to the experiment which is helpful to study and disclosure the eCO2RR-to-alcohol mechanism. However, engineering mono-M site has limited effect on the improvement of catalyst electrocatalytic performance to obtain high-purity and high-concentration alcohol products, so more active sites need to be introduced. It is worth noting that C is also a common non-metallic element used to regulate the metal local environment, but C itself is also considered to be a site for adsorbing and stabilizing *CO, making the active site of M/C material complicated and controversial, which goes beyond the scope of mono-M site(s). Therefore, we will summarize the strategy of introducing carbon materials to modify the metal active center in the subsequent ‘structure engineering’ part. 3.1.2 Alloying (Metal-Metal site) Coupling two metals in alloy or bimetallic materials to enrich the catalyst surface with well-defined abundant active sites can greatly enhance the performance of metal catalysts by tuning the stabilization degree of key intermediates. Generally, the intrinsic property of the secondary metal determines the electronic states of the catalyst, geometric distance between the surface atoms, and thus the reaction kinetics. Metals generating CO as the predominant product (Au, Ag, Pd, and Zn) are usually introduced as guest metal species to regulate the catalytic behavior of mono-Cu [40]. Because of their strong ability to produce CO, their introduction is conducive to increase the local CO concentration of metal active centers, which is conducive to their further reduction/coupling behavior. Alloys. For the eCO2RR-to-MeOH process, an intermediate *CO binding strength is often desired to prevent *CO desorption (at weak *CO binding surfaces i.e., Au, Ag) and *CO coupling/poisoning (at strong *CO binding surfaces i.e., Pd) [64,65]. In comparison with Cu, Pd in group III has a low overpotential for CO2 electroreduction, but high chemical affinity to CO and H makes it easy to be poisoned and hinders the deep reduction of CO2. Usually, the products are H2/CO/HCOOH [41,47,61,65]. Therefore, the manipulation of both adsorption and activation of CO is crucial in the design of Cu-Pd-based bimetallic catalysts to realize the selective production of alcohols. Hirunsit et al. theoretically studied the CO2 reduction to CH4 and MeOH on a range of Cu3M (where M = Au, Ag, Pd, Pt, Ni, Co, Rh, and Ir) alloy surfaces by DFT modeling [66]. They found that CH4 generation was more favorable than pure Cu, except for Cu3Pd and Cu3Pt, which favored a pathway to MeOH. While more experimental results on Cu3Pd were needed to further support the conclusions, it has theoretically proved that Cu-Pd bimetal system was conducive to the formation of MeOH which guided the follow-up research. Lu et al. prepared a serious of Pd x Cu y bimetallic aerogels with controlled composition as catalysts for eCO2RR [61]. They found that the efficiency of MeOH generation depends on the ratio of Pd to Cu. By using Pd83Cu17 bimetallic aerogels, an optimal FE for MeOH production can reach 80.0% with a current density of 31.8 mA cm−2, which is the highest FE for eCO2RR-to-MeOH by far. The varying composition in Pd x Cu y aerogels resulted in different Pd0/PdII and CuI + Cu0/CuII radios, which was found to be correlated with the CO2 electrocatalytic activity and MeOH selectivity. Nevertheless, both the interaction between Pd and Cu and how the ratio of Pd0/PdII and Pd/Cu influence the eCO2RR on the catalyst surface require further exploration. This study demonstrates that the introduction of another metal can effectively adjust the adsorption behavior of *CO on metal sites, and the product selectivity is highly determined by the proportion of metal components. Although Cu overlayers on tetrahexahedral Pd nanocrystals (THH Pd) and [PYD]@Cu-Pd showed high activity of eCO2RR to mixed alcohol products of EtOH and MeOH with optimal compositions, the FEs were below 20% [65,67]. Therefore, Cu-Pd system is generally designed for eCO2RR-to-MeOH process. However, as an element of Group III, Pd with strong H-binding leads to dominant HER competitive reaction and a higher proportion of hydrocarbon products. Therefore, Pd is not an ideal metal active site for eCO2RR-to-alcohols. Ag, Au and Zn in group I with weak H and O binding are more commonly used co-metal sites in the eCO2RR-to-alcohol catalyst [40]. Ag and Au are d-block metals with weak CO adsorption ability and relatively high overpotential of hydrogen evolution which have been well studied as guest metals to form alloy or bimetallic materials with Cu for eCO2RR. Mechanistically, the desorption of CO on Cu sites was promoted because of the lower activation energy for CO desorption caused by Au alloying. It was found that both the composition and nanostructure of Cu-Au alloys affected the catalytic performance, such that MeOH and EtOH were selectively produced [68]. Jia et al. prepared nanostructured CuAu alloys with optimal compositions for eCO2RR, which showed special catalytic activity towards mixed alcohols (MeOH and EtOH) in aqueous system [68]. FEs of MeOH and EtOH on Cu63.9Au36.1 were analyzed to be 15.9% and 12%, respectively, ∼19 times than that on pure Cu. To effectively produce EtOH, it is important to optimize the adsorption behavior of the selective-dependent intermediate *CH2CHO and promote its hydrogenation by introducing guest metals. As a typical example, it was discovered that the selective eCO2RR to EtOH with an FE of 29 ± 4% could be achieved using the AuCu alloy nanoparticles (NPs) embedded Cu submicrocone arrays (AuCu/Cu-SCA) with optimal Au content (Fig. 4 a and b) [69]. By varying the ratio of Cu/Au in the alloy NPs, the distribution of EtOH and ethylene could be tuned. The coupling experimental and DFT calculation results disclosed the contribution of Au for tuning the binding strength of critical intermediates (*CH2CHO, *CH3CHO, and *CH3CH2O) and thereby modulated the activity and selectivity toward eCO2RR (Fig. 4c). Similarly, the Cu-Ag electrocatalysts were designed to favor the stabilization of *HCCHOH (C2H5OH pathway) while hinder the transformation of *CCH (C2H4 pathway). Sargent and co-workers synthesized a bimetallic Ag/Cu catalyst via modulating the Cu surface with Ag and consequently led to the binding sites diversity to boost the EtOH production through disrupting the intermediates in the ethylene path, while the FE for EtOH was still less than 50% (Fig. 4d–f) [35]. Tandem catalyst. In the above studies, the introduction of M directly affected the adsorption behavior of key intermediates by regulating the electronic valence and chemical environment of Cu-site. However, metals (i.e., Au, Ag, Zn) other than Cu have negligible ability for deep reduction of CO2. It is found that the guest metal species generally play an assistant role in the bimetallic catalysts by increasing local CO concentration on Cu to be further reduced to alcohols. Considering the experimental results that the performance of CORR-to-EtOH on Cu electrode is much better than that of CO2RR-to-EtOH, the concept of ‘tandem catalysts’ has been proposed and applied in the field of eCO2RR (Fig. 5 a) [70,71]. On the basis of separating the multi-electron transfer process of eCO2RR-to-EtOH, the ‘tandem catalysts’ provide the possibility for separating the M-M site to distinct M and M active sites thus decoupling adsorption energy of intermediates on each site which provides a new idea for the strategy of component regulation. Inspired by the intrinsic weak and high binding strength with CO of Ag/Au/Zn and Cu, respectively, coupling Ag/Au/Zn as a CO-producing catalyst and Cu as a second catalyst to perform tandem eCO2RR is a new way for producing deep reduction compounds (Fig. 5b and c) [72]. In a pioneering work, Yeo’s group introduced Zn as a co-catalyst with Cu to perform eCO2RR with a high FE of 29.1% toward C2H5OH at −1.05 V vs. RHE [73]. A two-site mechanism is proposed: firstly, CO2 can be reduced to CO on both Zn and Cu sites; afterwards, the formed CO on Zn sites could easily desorb and pass to Cu sites as an in situ source to transform to *CH x (x = 1–3); Then, the insertion of CO to the Cu-*CH2 produced the intermediate of *COCH2 which further protonates to alcohol products. Afterwards, Morales-Guio et al. deposited Au NPs on polycrystalline Cu foil to prepare Au/Cu bimetallic tandem electrocatalyst which boosted the activity and selectivity for >2e− reduction products, outperforming bare Au, Cu and AuCu alloys (Fig. 5e) [74]. The in-depth analysis through transport modelling unveiled the individual role of Au and Cu in the tandem mechanism. Similar to Zn and Au, Ag can also produce a high concentration of *CO on the neighbouring Cu surface and ensure the saturated *CO to be continuously reduced to EtOH and n-PrOH. Most recently, Zhang et al. designed Cu@Ag core-shell NPs to realize the tandem catalysis by producing CO on Ag shell and further achieving C–C coupling on Cu core toward C2 valuables which demonstrated the effect of morphology on tandem catalysis and expanded the range of tandem catalysts [75]. However, the role of each active center in alloy catalysts is difficult to define due to the mass transport effect in such catalysts which makes it hard to determine intrinsic kinetics. Therefore, the boundary between traditional alloy catalyst and tandem catalyst remain ambiguous. More importantly, there remains a general question in the tandem catalysis system: what the status of the locally generated CO is (bound or adsorbed *CO vs. unbound and gaseous CO) [44]. At present, the universally accepted propose based on DFT analysis is that the spilled-over CO is more likely to take part in the formation of EtOH in the form of adsorbed state [76]. While studies of diffusional simulations suggest the concentration of locally generated CO can exceed its saturation limit [77]. Therefore, more well-designed catalysts coupled with more advanced characterizations are needed to further clarify the mechanism of tandem catalysis for the eCO2RR-to-C2+ alcohols. 3.1.3 Heteroatom doping (Non-Metal site) At present, the above-mentioned metal species are common active sites for the eCO2RR process. However, these metals are also active for the competitive HER process and suffer from agglomeration and subsequent deactivation, which would decrease the FE of eCO2RR and lead to low stability [78]. Therefore, the development of catalysts with non-metallic active centers is desired to achieve high-efficiency eCO2RR-to-alcohol process. N-doping. Carbon materials with high electrical conductivity, large accessible surface area and good structure stability are promising alternative for metal-based catalysts. When doping with heteroatoms (i.e., N, B), the intrinsic physical and chemical properties can be significantly tailored, which endows them with good catalytic functions toward eCO2RR [45,78–84]. Since the N atom has a similar structure to C atoms and wide natural sources, N-doping strategy has been widely applied for the modification of carbon-based catalyst for eCO2RR [84–87]. Recently, N-doped carbon nanofibers/nanotubes/graphenes/diamond have been used as effective catalysts for CO2 electroreduction, which reduce CO2 to CO, HCHO or HCOOH with maximum FE of 74.0%–87.0% [78,88]. However, the products obtained by these N-doped carbon nanostructures are limited, which have weak ability to stabilize the active C1 intermediates for their dimer or further reduction to generate products beyond CO, especially C2 products. Only a few metal-free catalysts can achieve the efficient alcohol production relying on the active site of N-doped carbon. As a typical example, Wu et al. reported the N-doped graphene quantum dots (NGQDs) to catalyze the eCO2RR into multi-carbon hydrocarbons and oxygenates which showed a high total FE of CO2 reduction of up to 90%, with selectivity for ethylene and EtOH conversions reaching 45% [86]. The C2 and C3 product distribution and production rate catalyzed by NGQD were comparable to those obtained with Cu-based electrocatalysts. Based on the ex-situ post-reaction X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results, the pyridinic N located at the edge site favored the CO2 adsorption. This pioneering finding expanded the horizon for the design of metal-free N-doped electrocatalysts for eCO2RR to deep reduction products. However, the reaction mechanism of electroreduction of CO2 over N-doped carbon materials remained elusive which require the combination of high-sensitive operando spectroscopy and first-principle calculation to provide insight into the reaction intermediates and reveal the reaction pathways. Following this work, Song et al. developed a class of mesoporous N-doped carbons (c-NC) which can convert CO2 into EtOH with FE as high as 77% at the low potential of @ −0.56 V (vs. RHE) [88]. The combined experiments and DFT calculations demonstrated the preferential formation of CO* on pyridinic N sites for the dimerization of the CO* intermediates to EtOH formation, proved the findings by previous reports. Therefore, the doping form and coordination environment of N had a great impact on the adsorption behavior of key intermediates. Most recently, in order to screen out the structure of N-doped graphene with highest reaction activity, Liu et al calculated the frontier molecular orbital energy and energy difference of 1–3 N atom-modified graphene. The reaction pathways of eCO2RR-to-EtOH with different sites in mono/binary/ternary N-doped graphenes were discussed [85]. It was found that all of them dramatically reduced the free energy of the final product EtOH comparing to the bare graphene catalyst. Compared to other N configurations in graphene, site 43 at the 2e configuration of binary-N-doped graphene exhibited the best catalytic performance for the eCO2RR due to its lowest rising potential barrier. Therefore, this study theoretically provided ideas for the design of N-doped carbon-based catalysts for the eCO2RR-to-EtOH process. It is also highly desirable to accurately control the configuration of N experimentally. B-doping. In addition to doping with electron-rich element N, the introduction of electron deficient element B is also a common modification strategy [81,83,89,90]. For example, boron-doped diamond (BDD) was designed to efficiently catalyze eCO2RR-to-MeOH in weakly alkaline aqueous NH3 solution with FE of 24.3% at −1.3 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) [89]. Furthermore, boron phosphide nanoparticles are developed as a metal-free electrocatalyst for highly efficient and selective eCO2RR-to-MeOH which reached a remarkable high FE for MeOH of 92.0% at −0.5 V (vs. RHE) in 0.1 M KHCO3 [83]. Combined experiments and DFT calculations reveal the electronic interactions between B and P which can synergistically promote the binding and activation of CO2. The FEMeOH obtained by BP has been the highest value reached by metal-free catalysts to date, which even outperformed many advanced metal catalysts thus placed the BP among the best catalysts for eCO2RR-to-MeOH. Therefore, this study attracks research interests in developing metal-free catalysts with dual-dopants to boost eCO2RR performance for deep reduction products via the synergistic effect. N,B-co doping. Given the above-mentioned merits of N and B doping, the eCO2RR activity of carbon nanomaterials was further improved via the synergistic effect of B and N co-doping [81,90]. As reported by Liu et al., a remarkable FEEtOH of 93.2% at −1.0 V (vs. RHE) was achieved on B- and N-co-doped diamond (BND) [90]. The synergistic effect of B and N was revealed by DFT analysis. At first, the B atom enhanced the CO2 capture by bonding with one O atom of absorbed CO2; subsequently, the N facilitated *H transfer in the elementary reactions involving hydrogenation. The synergy is quite similar to that of ‘tandem catalyst’ for eCO2RR-to-EtOH, in which one site assists CO adsorption and stabilization while the other site promotes a deep reduction. Therefore, developing metal-free heteroatom-doped carbon materials is beneficial for exploring the non-metallic site active for eCO2RR and reveals its intrinsic properties in electrolysis which can provide general principles in introducing nonmetallic elements for the design of other efficient catalysts. More importantly, carbon materials can serve as supports to be combined with metal sites, which is a widely adopted strategy in designing eCO2RR-to-alcohols catalyst with higher performance and lower cost. In brief summary, component regulation based on active site is the fundamental strategy to regulate the adsorption behavior of active sites for key intermediates, thus significantly affecting the reaction pathways. The activity and variability of a single active site are limited. Introducing other metal and non-metal elements to form alloys and compounds to construct multiple active sites can effectively regulate the reaction activity and product distribution in eCO2RR. The traditional catalyst design concept regards the complex formed by two elements as one active site to realize the improvement of catalytic activity and selectivity by tuning the element ratios; while the concept of tandem catalysis further combined the multi-step characteristics of eCO2RR with component regulation strategy. Specifically, for catalysts of eCO2RR towards alcohols which involves complicated paths and wide product distribution, the component regulation strategy of tandem catalysis can not only regulate the chemical environment of active sites, but also realize the separation of intermediates, so as to hold greater potential for mechanism research and practical applications. 3.2 Nanostructure construction The component regulation strategy is mainly based on the design of a single active site, while the arrangement of active sites on the surface and throughout the architecture will also regulate the adsorption behavior of the key intermediates, thereby affecting the efficiency and product distribution of eCO2RR. For micro/nanostructure design principles, the construction of three-dimensional (3D) structure is conducive to the diffusion of electrolyte and the exposure of catalytic active sites, so as to increase the numbers of active sites and improve the electroactivity in many electrochemical energy-related reactions. It is found that rough surfaces, 3D and porous structure contribute to the improvement of eCO2RR-to-alcohol performance [91]. Dendrite-structure. Dendrite-structure has been widely applied for the design of eCO2RR catalyst attributing to the roughened surfaces, fully exposure of optimal facets and intrinsic hydrophobicity [92–94]. A pulse-deposited (PD) Zn catalyst on Ag foams (PD-Zn/Ag) was designed using the metal foam as template to disperse PD Zn into submicron dendrites which contained stretched undercoordinated Zn sites active for eCO2RR-to-MeOH [92]. The PD-Zn/Ag showed a tenfold increase in FEMeOH of 10.5% under a constant current of 26 mA cm−2 with respect to previous AgZn catalysts. Similarly, 3D dendritic Cu-Cu2O/Cu electrodes for eCO2RR were prepared by electroreduction of in situ deposited Cu-complex film on Cu substrate which exhibited outstanding performance for eCO2RR-to-C2 product with total FEC2 of 80% and TOF of EtOH to be 15.6 h−1 [93]. The 3D structure provided abundant active sites and reduced contacting resistance between the catalysts and the substrate which contributed to the enhanced efficiency for the reduction of CO2 to EtOH products. The impact of morphological changes on tuning selectivity of eCO2RR towards multicarbon alcohol products were firstly reported by Rahaman et al [94]. The identical location inspection of the nanodendritic Cu catalysts on the individual stages of their preparation process was visualized and the morphological origin of boosted selectivity toward multicarbon alcohols formation (total FEalcohol = 24.8% at −1.0 V vs. RHE, FEPrOH = 13.1% at −0.9 V) after the subsequent thermal annealing treatment was confirmed. Hollow structure. Since alcohols are the deep reduction products of eCO2RR, increasing the local concentration of CO has been proved to improve the activity of eCO2RR-to-alcohols. The design of hollow and nanocavity structure is conducive to capture and confine CO species for further reduction, so as to improve the efficiency of eCO2RR to products beyond CO [95]. For example, a hollow urchin-like Co(CO3)0.5(OH)·0.11H2O was designed for highly selective eCO2RR-to-MeOH with a remarkable FE of 97.0% at −0.98 V (vs. saturated calomel electrode (SCE)) attributing to the fast transfer and diffusion of the MeOH product [95]. A metal-free N-doped mesoporous carbon with ordered cylindrical channel structures was successfully developed for highly efficient and selective eCO2RR-to-EtOH with FE of 77% at @ −0.56 V (vs. RHE), outperforming the counterpart of inverse mesoporous N-doped carbon without cylindrical tunnels [88]. The experiments and DFT calculations demonstrated the enhanced adsorption of *CO intermediates by the cylindrical structures which promoted *CO dimerization and EtOH formation. Inspired by such confinement effect, Zhuang et al. provided a comprehensive model by the finite-element method (FEM) simulations to study the effect of the nanocavity confinement structure on C2 intermediates and synthesized a 3D nanocavity Cu catalyst with FEPrOH of 21% ± 1% at −0.56 V (vs. RHE) [55]. The reaction pathway of eCO2RR-to-PrOH was revealed by computed concentration and flux distribution of species which suggested that the cavity restricted the outflow of locally produced C2 species thus led to higher local C2 intermediate concentrations inside cavity to be further reduced to C3 alcohol. These findings provide a physical route to tuning chemical selectivity and enabling the multicarbon liquid fuels production by eCO2RR. Carbon supports. On the basis that both transition-metal species and carbon-based materials are active for eCO2RR-to-alcohol process, dispersing metal sites on carbon materials is demonstrated to be an effective strategy for catalyst design. When applying carbon-based materials (i.e., graphenes, carbon nanotubes, diamond) as matrixs, the conductivity of the catalyst can be improved while the interface interactions between M and C further promote the electron transfers. For the production of alcohols, the carbon-based materials with oxophilicitiy play an important role for the stabilization of oxygen-containing intermediates (*OCH x , *OH, and *O) and strengthen the binding of *CO on metal sites, therefore boosting the eCO2RR-to-alcohol activity. Different types of carbon matrix can be used, such as carbon nanodots (0-D), carbon nanotubes (1-D), the graphene family (2-D), and carbon frameworks and diamond (3-D). It is to be noticed that the activity and selectively of eCO2RR on these carbon-based materials are greatly affected by the nature of the metal, distribution of metal particles and properties of the carbon matrix. For example, Cu-supported carbon nanotube (Cu/CNT) exhibited FEMeOH of 38.4% at −1.7 V (vs. SCE) [96]. While an FEMeOH of 38% was achieved on Cu2O-multi-walled CNTs at −0.8 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) [97]. The 3D porous carbon-supported OD Cu (OD Cu/C) obtained by carbonization of Cu-based MOF exhibited the FE of 13.8%–8.3% and 31.4%–34.8% for MeOH and EtOH at −0.5 to −0.7 V (vs. RHE), respectively [98]. The well-dispersed metal NPs, hierarchical porous structures, and large surface areas all account for the high activity of eCO2RR-to-alcohols. It is worth noting that the as-obtained FEs were inferior to those achieved on the aforementioned metal free N-doped carbon materials, which highlights the importance on modification of carbon matrix to further boost the eCO2RR-to-alcohol activities. Guided by the DFT analysis results that the CO dimerization barrier of N-C layer on the Cu surface (N-C/Cu) is lower than that of bare C layer on the Cu surface (C/Cu), Wang et al. prepared N-C/Cu catalysts with FEEtOH of (52 ± 1)% at −0.68 V (vs. RHE) under a current density of 300 mA cm−2 [36]. The in-situ Raman and synchrotron X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) characterization results suggested that the N-C layer with strong electron-donating ability can promote the C–C coupling and suppress the breaking of the C–O bond in HOCCH* through the confinement-covering effect, as proved by DFT theoretical calculations. The N-doped graphenes with large surface area and good conductivity are also applied as carbon matrixs for dispersion of metal sites which can catalyze eCO2RR for the production of C1-C3 alcohols [99,100]. Chen et al. discovered the N-doped graphene quantum dots (NGQ) on CuO-derived Cu nanorods (NGQ/Cu-nr) as an efficient catalyst for eCO2RR which showed a total FE of C2+ alcohols of 75.3% at −0.7 V (vs. RHE), with the FE of PrOH reaching up to 27.2%, which is one of the highest FE of C3 alcohols [100]. Experimental and DFT studies indicated a different mechanism from ‘tandem catalysis’ which attributed the increase of C2+ alcohols production to oxophilicity of the NGQ/Cu-nr and the dual active sites of NGQ and Cu-nr. A Co/single-layer N-doped graphene (SL-NG) catalyst also showed high activity for eCO2RR-to-MeOH, attaining a high FEMeOH of 71.4% at −0.9 V (vs. SCE) [101]. It is worth noting that Co is not a general active metal species for eCO2RR, but when its chemical environment is finely adjusted, the catalytic activity can be improved which emphasized the importance to regulate the coordination environment of metal sites. It is worth noting that the applications of carbon materials play dual roles in both nanostructure and atomic structure engineering, making it a promising support for eCO2RR-to-alcohol catalyst design. 4 Rational interface design for eCO2RR-to-alcohols 4.1 Surface structure engineering 4.1.1 Confinement Molecule catalysts. Recent computational studies of M-N4 molecular structures (a metal centre coordinated with four nitrogen atoms) found that CO binding was moderate on Co-N4 [43,102]. Then Wu et al. reported a noncovalent anchoring strategy which enabled catalytic molecules of CoPc with Co-N4 structure to be highly dispersed on the surface of a highly conductive CNT network [102]. The FE for MeOH production of 44% were achieved on CoPc/CNT at −0.82 V (vs. RHE) which is the first example of transition-metal-based molecular electrocatalyst to catalyze eCO2RR-to-MeOH with an appreciable yield. They highlighted the importance of stabilizing active sites through coordination atom confinement during the long-term electrolysis to further improve the stability of CoPc/CNT which deactivated within 5-hour electrolysis. Single atom catalysts. Anchored metal single atoms (SAs) with M-N x structure on carbon materials might be an ideal choice due to their maximum atomic utilization, unique electronic structure and stable coordination environment [103–105]. It has been reported that Ni-N4-O/C and Ni@NiNCM catalysts with Ni-N x structure could reduce CO2 to CO with nearly 100% selectivity [103,104]. Unfortunately, M-N-C electrocatalysts mainly produced the 2e reduction products of CO and formate so far. There are few reports on the further reduction of CO2 to hydrocarbons or alcohols catalyzed by M-N-C materials. The most typical example is the Cu single atoms (CuSAs) distributed on throughhole carbon nanofibers (TCNFs) for efficient eCO2RR which exhibited superior FE (44% at −0.9 V vs. RHE) and partial current density (93 mA cm−2) of MeOH as well as long-term stability for more than 50 h [105]. Considering the difficulty of obtaining C2+ product on SAs with typically mono-active site, it is surprising to see the boosted eCO2RR-to-EtOH activity on Cu SAs dispersed on carbon black (Cu/C) [106]. Experimental study, combining with the DFT calculation revealed a dynamic reversible transformation between Cu SA and Cu n (n = 3 and 4) NPs under eCO2RR potentials which served as real active sites for promoting the C–C coupling while the ligation of the transient Cu active site by the hydroxyl group on carbon surface accounted for the main distinction in controlling the selectivity to EtOH between this Cu/C catalyst versus the reported Cu on N-doped carbon [106]. A similar transformation of Cu particle during electrolysis were also reported by Kim et al. which revealed the structural evolution of Cu NP to active cube-like particles for eCO2RR with FE of C2–C3 (ethylene, EtOH, and PrOH) reaching 50% at only −0.75 V (vs. RHE) [107]. However, the real active sites and mechanism for the formation of C3 products remained unclear. Therefore, further investigation into the evolution of valence, morphology and coordination environment of catalytic active sites in eCO2RR is needed, which will guide the catalyst design through the elaborate manipulation on single atoms, nanoclusters and nanoparticles to realize the high alcohols selectivity especially towards the multicarbon alcohols. 4.1.2 Crystal facet engineering Engineering of the surface structure in atomic-level is a compelling method for adjusting the exposed surface reactive atoms precisely and thus promoting the relevant electrochemical performance [108]. The strategy of crystal facet engineering can not only optimize the catalyst properties through the selective exposure of the favorable crystal facets for intermediates adsorption, but also apply to design and synthesize shape controlled nanocatalysts, where both the surface area and the exposed facet can be controlled [109,110]. For eCO2RR to alcohols, the selectivity depends on the adsorption behavior of the common intermediates in the pathways towards hydrocarbons and alcohols. Owing to the intrinsic property of Cu for producing alcohol products, the researches on crystal facet engineering mostly concentrated on Cu-based catalysts. For C1 alcohol (CH3OH) production, the extent of CH4 and CH3OH formation sensitively depends on the surface orientation of the Cu electrode, while the conclusion is still controversial. Some researches claimed (111) facet was the dominant plane of Cu, which kinetically favored the *OCH3 → CH3OH step, while others report discovered that the formation of CH4 was preferential [111]. Therefore, more theoretical, experimental and characterization studies are required to further determine the dominant crystal plane of MeOH selective production. Regarding C2 alcohol (C2H5OH) production, Bagger et al. systematically studied the eCO2RR to C2+ products on various facets of Cu by calculating the coordination number distribution and the binding energies of the intermediates based on DFT (Fig. 6 a and b) [110]. It was found that the (100) basal plane with the specific (110) step of Cu increased C2H5OH production, confirming the experiment results by Hori et al. which observed the incorporation of (110) step sites on the (100) terrace sites boosted the FE of ETOH production to 29.9% [112]. More importantly, specific facets such as Cu (100), Cu (111), and Cu (331) have also been proposed to thermodynamically favor C–C coupling by both theoretical and experimental results [112]. The above strategies for crystal facet engineering are based on the regulation of atom arrangement within the facets. The most recent study by Jeong et al. has proposed a novel strategy to realize the high activity and C2+ product selectivity for the eCO2RR through regulating the atomic-scale spacings (ds) between two crystal planes (Fig. 6c) [113]. When parallel Cu (100) and Cu (111) surfaces spaced ∼5–6 Å apart, the DFT calculations revealed the downhill of C–C coupling process while an order of magnitude increase in the current density and product selectivity to ethylene and EtOH rising to nearly 80% was achieved (Fig. 6d). Therefore, control of ds between the facets extended the strategy of crystal facet engineering to a new dimension. It is worth mentioning that the as-applied crystal facet engineering strategies have significantly impact on the C–C coupling process, thereby boosted the eCO2RR activity to C2+ products. Jiang et al. controlled the surface morphology and facet exposure by tuning the battery cycle numbers on Cu foils for high-value C2+ products [114]. However, the impact on increasing the selectivity of EtOH to ethylene is limited. Therefore, further investigations on the facet-dependence of oxygen-containing intermediates (i.e., *HOCCH, *CH2CHO) is expected to shed light on promoting the alcohols formation through crystal facet engineering. 4.1.3 Defect engineering Apart from the well-defined facets, defect is another important aspect on surface structure to regulate the charge distribution and adsorption behaviors of the intermediates. Generally, the introduction of defects (i.e., dopants, atom/ion vacancies, grain boundaries) in the crystal lattice can not only change the coordination environment of surface atoms, but also break the charge balance near the catalyst surface, facilitating electron transportation and flexibly adjusting adsorption of key intermediates during electrolysis [115]. Therefore, defect engineering in various materials, such as alloys and metal oxides, is an effective strategy to enhance the surface activity and selectivity toward alcohol productions by eCO2RR [116]. In polycrystalline materials, a large number of defects are usually observed at grain boundaries (GBs) with high activity [116]. The properties of grain-boundary-rich metallic Cu obtained by additive-controlled electrodeposition was improved by the abundant active sites in the GB, reaching a high selectivity of ethylene and EtOH of 70% (Fig. 7 a and b) [117]. A recent study has explored that the environment in electrodeposition process had significant impact on defect construction of Cu electrode. Gu et al. reported a defect-site-rich Cu catalyst (Cu-DS) via electrodeposition under a CO-rich environment which promoted the formation of GB-rich surfaces (Fig. 7e–j) [118]. The Cu-DS catalyst greatly enhances the CO2-to-alcohol reduction, achieving the FE of 70% and high current densities over 100 mA cm−2, significantly outperforms the Cu catalyst with flat surfaces (Cu-C) formed without *CO adsorbates. In addition to the grain boundaries inside a monometallic component, the grain boundaries in bimetallic materials between two metals are also found to boost the activity of the catalyst in the eCO2RR to EtOH process. For example, Lee and coworkers reported the boosted EtOH selectivity of phase-blended CuAg alloy which significantly outperformed the catalytic properties of phase-separated components (Fig. 7c and d) [119]. The Ag-Cu biphasic boundaries and Ag-Cu atom distance was beneficial to mobile the generated CO from Ag to Cu site, thus favoring EtOH formation instead of ethylene pathway. Ion/atom vacancies have been demonstrated as a category of catalytic sites for enhancing CO2 activation and *C1 adsorption in eCO2RR process. Metal oxides with oxygen vacancies (VOs) have specific interaction with oxy-species which are widely applied for alcohol productions. The VO, metal active sites and interface between metal and metal oxides synergistically enhanced the catalytic properties. For instance, Daiyan et al. reported a 3D Cu sandwich electrode for eCO2RR which achieved an FE of 31% for EtOH production attributing to the rich Cu+/Cu2+ interface and abundant oxygen vacancies [120]. Derived from copper oxide, copper sulfide has also attracted great interest because stable surface defects and surface vacancies can be precisely controlled by various methods under mild conditions. In a pioneering work, Sargent and co-workers systematically developed a series of core–shell Cu2S-Cu-V (where V denotes vacancy) electrocatalysts via solvothermal method to incorporate S into Cu structure (Fig. 8 a) [54]. The controllable introduction of S atoms in the catalyst core and Cu vacancies in its shell led to a notable difference in the ratio of EtOH/ethylene products by eCO2RR. DFT calculations revealed the role of vacancies which lowered the overpotential to overcome early C–C coupling energy barrier. As a result, the subsurface S atoms and Cu vacancy defects together shifted the balance towards EtOH by suppressing ethylene production and realized the eCO2RR to multi-carbon alcohols: FEs of 15% ± 1% for EtOH and 8% ± 0.7% for PrOH at −0.95 V vs. RHE, respectively (Fig. 8b). In addition to constructing cation Cu vacancies, the surface S atoms can also be removed to form S vacancies, designated as CuS x (0 < x < 1). The sulfur vacancies can regulate the oxidation of Cu, which has been proved to promote C–C coupling towards alcohols. Most recently, Peng et al. designed a double-sulfur vacancy (DSV) structure using a lithium electrochemical tuning approach, which allowed for stabilization of *CO and facilitate CO–OCCO coupling to form C3 species (Fig. 8c) [121]. The DSV-rich CuS x catalyst exhibited a boosted FE of 15.4% ± 1% for PrOH at −1.05 V vs. RHE (Fig. 8d). Through electrochemical lithium tuning process, the density of sulfur vacancies could be well-controlled by the charge/discharge cycle number which provided a novel strategy to create anion vacancy pairs for eCO2RR towards multi-carbon-products (Fig. 8e). In brief summary, rational design of catalysts by activating the ‘intrinsic catalytic activity’ of each site via component regulation, increasing the ‘active sites numbers’ via nanostructure construction and optimizing the ‘surface atomic arrangement’ can boost the performance of eCO2RR-to-alcohol. The advancements of the catalysts for eCO2RR-to-alcohols in recent years are summerized in Table 3. 4.2 Microenvironment engineering After the successful design and fabrication of a catalyst, the realization of its optimal performance is affected by actual electrolytic environment, mainly including electrode structure and electrolyte. Therefore, although great progress of electocatalysts has been made, the current density and yield of high-valued chemical products are far below the industrially relevant requirements which are limited by low solubility of CO2 in aqueous electrolyte solutions (~30 mM). As the eCO2RR is a heterogeneous reaction which involves three-phase interface of solid (catalyst)/liquid (electrolyte)/gas (CO2 reactant and potential gas products), several strategies have been proposed to manipulate on micro-interface environments to increase the available concentration of CO2. In this part, we briefly overview the strategies to achieve the optimal performance for the eCO2RR to alcohols from the two major aspects of electrode design and electrolyte modulation. 4.2.1 Upgraded electrode design Compared with commonly used conventional electrodes, gas diffusion electrodes (GDEs) have shown great potential for eCO2RR of various products under high current density which validly solves the problem of low CO2 solubility and promotes CO2 mass transfer through the design of gas–solid-liquid interface [35,126]. The GDE configuration comprises of two sides: one side of a catalyst layer on a porous hydrophobic substrate, i.e., the gas diffusion layer (GDL) and the other side of the cathode exposing to the feeding gas, thus the liquid and gas phase within the catalyst layers greatly shortens the diffusion path of CO2 in the electrolyte. Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) with porous structures was found to efficiently capture and isolate CO2, which increase the concentration of reactant CO2 on the electrode surface and thus benefit the electrochemical transformation of CO2 to target products. For example, Albo et al. reported the synthesis of GDEs based on Cu-Bi bimetallic MOFs (MOF-GDEs) which exhibited favorable continuous transformation of CO2 under a large current density of 100 mA cm−2 with FEs of 8.6% and 28.3% for MeOH and EtOH, respectively [126]. Higher current densities up to −400 mA cm−2 were achieved in a flow cell reactor using a GDE. The AgCu catalyst was deposited on a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) substrate to form GDL which allowed the diffusion of gaseous CO2 through the GDL and reach the catalyst/solution interface. As a result, the highest FE (37%) for EtOH was achieved at a large current density of 300 mA cm−2 (Fig. 9 a and b) [35]. However, the local pH increases sharply when conducting the CO2 electrolysis at high current densities [127]. The competing HER is suppressed in high pH electrolytes, but high OH− concentrations drive the CO2 to react in carbonate equilibrium reactions at a rate comparable to that of the electrode reaction [128]. As a result, this parasitic chemical loss of dissolved CO2 can account for over 50% of the total CO2 consumption at high current densities. This reduces reactant utilization and leads to relatively low CO2 solubility due to the salting-out effect in the resulting high ionic-strength electrolyte [129,130]. High concentrations of carbonate can also lead to salt precipitation and loss of hydrophobicity in the GDL, progressively hinder the diffusion of CO2 and thereby lead to a low stability under long-term operation [131]. Most recently, Xu et al. reported a self-cleaning CO2 reduction strategy on Cu-PTFE by alternating voltage to avoid saturation and prevent carbonate salt formation which maintained a C2 product selectivity of 80% and a C2 partial current density of 138 mA cm−2 for 157 h, outperformed the Cu-PTFE operated under continuous electrolysis (Fig. 10 a) [132]. Therefore, the micro-environment of GDE can be regulated by operating the electrolysis conditions, so as to improve the stability of GDE under high current density [133]. For the production of volatile EtOH, high CO2-rate electrolysis under high current density will also cause the evaporation of alcohol from GDE, which is usually ignored (Fig. 9c and d) [134]. Niu et al. proposed a modified measurement protocol by introducing on-line GC for quantification through a mass flowmeter, allowing us to detect liquid products of CO2 electrolysis more accurately (Fig. 10b) [134]. 4.2.2 Electrolyte modulation Electrolyte is considered to be an important factor that affecting eCO2RR by providing interaction with electrode surface, reactants, intermediates and products and also a media for accelerating the transformation of coupled electrons and protons. The catalytic efficiencies of electrocatalysts in terms of activity and selectivity can be significantly influenced by the type and concentration of electrolytes. For example, a recent study has sparked new insights that water played an essential role in the formation of EtOH from eCO2RR [135]. Additionally, a trace amount of pyridoxine-based molecules in electrolytes and water in some inoic liquid (IL) electrolytes could effectively improve the eCO2RR performance [135–138]. Hence, rational design of electrolyte could be an append approach to enhance alcohols selectivity. Generally, three kinds of electrolytes, including aqueous solutions, organic electrolytes and ionic liquids (ILs), have been explored for CO2RR. Herein, we focus on the recent progress in aqueous and organic solutions according to the preference of alcohol products generation. Considering the high cost and poor stability in water, ILs are always served as co-catalysts or additives to further tune the catalytic performance for alcohol productions from CO2RR. Inorganic aqueous electrolytes. With regard to aqueous solutions, most of exploited catalysis systems for eCO2RR are conducted in acidic or basic aqueous electrolytes containing inorganic salts with appropriate anions and metal cations. The two kinds of ions play different roles in eCO2RR process. Regarding metal cations, the charge and size of cations significantly affected the rate of eCO2RR and the product selectivity [139,140]. The high reaction rate of eCO2RR to MeOH was demonstrated to be correlated to the high valence state of electrolyte cations [140]. Whereas the role of cation size is to determine the product selectivity depending on the applied electrode [139,141]. Large size cations will facilitate the eCO2RR rather than HER [142]. Anionic species are reported to affect the local pH near the electrode and thus the selectivity of produced products. Hori et al. found that a high local pH can suppress HER due to the low proton concentration and they discovered that alcohols could be formed in the anionic electrolytes under a non-equilibrium local high pH [143]. More importantly, it was observed that the presence of halides (Cl−, Br−, and I−) in the electrolyte will significantly affect the CO2 electroreduction rate on oxidized Cu systems which is mainly attributed to the morphology evolution caused by the adsorbed halides [144]. When the Cu foil was introduced in the electrolyte containing I−, some well-defined Cu crystals were formed. The addition of halides increased the current densities and FE of C2-C3 alcohols, following the trend no halide < Cl− < Br− < I−, consistent with the fact that I− induced the most significant morphological change (Fig. 11 a–c). Inspired by the structural evolution of catalyst induced by the electrolyte with different anions at the applied potential and the increased FE of C2+ products, an electrolyte-driven nanostructuring strategy was applied to controllably synthesize eCO2RR catalysts [145]. A series of nano-structured Cu catalysts were synthesized and modified in the KHCO3 electrolyte containing KI salt for CO2 conversion to C2+ products, such as ethylene, EtOH, and PrOH, with an FE of 80% at −0.9 V vs. RHE (Fig. 11e) [146]. The adsorbed halides on the surface resulted in rough surface morphology, subsurface oxygen and Cu+ species which contributed to the high C2+ selectivity. Combining with the cation size effect, Gao et al. introduced Cs+ with larger size than K+ through replacing the electrolyte of KHCO3 to CsHCO3. The coexistence of Cs+ and I− induced drastic restructuring of the CuO x surface and formed shaped particles containing stable CuI species which is more favorable for the stabilization of the intermediates towards C2+ species (Fig. 11d) [145]. Although the role of cations has been revealed, the role of I− in facilitating C–C coupling is still ambiguous. Li et al. further revealed the role of adsorbed iodine in the Cu-CuI composite under electrolyte-driven restructuring process [147]. The DFT calculation results provide direct evidence that the binding energy of the key *CO intermediate was decreased by the adsorbed iodine species, which promoted C–C coupling process and thereby high-rate of eCO2RR to C2+ products (Fig. 11f). Electrolyte containing organic compounds. In comparison with aqueous electrolytes, the use of electrolytes containing organic compounds can promote the eCO2RR via improving CO2 adsorption and thereby facilitate the formation of more alcohol products [135–138]. For instance, Albo et al. examined the catalytic performance of eCO2RR to MeOH over a Cu2O/ZnO gas diffusion electrode in pyridine-based aqueous electrolyte [60]. It was claimed that the added pyridine-based organic molecular could reduce the overpotential due to the inductive effect originated from the pyridine-based molecule containing electron donor groups. Consequently, the enhanced energy efficiency of eCO2RR to MeOH catalyzed by Cu2O/ZnO electrocatalyst was improved to an FE of 25.6% for MeOH at 0.62 V vs. Ag/AgCl, which significantly outperformed that of the catalysis system in absence of molecular catalyst. Imidazole-groups could also be used in heterogeneous CO2RR. ILs with aromatic N-heterocyclic molecules are known to adsorb CO2 with high efficiency and stabilize the activated CO2 reduction intermediates [148,149]. Han and co-workers applied the Mo-Bi bimetallic chalcogenides on carbon paper (BMC/CP) electrode in the electrolyte of methyl cyanide (MeCN) containing 0.5 M 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ([Bmim]BF4) [124]. MeOH was the only liquid product with FE of 71.2% at −0.7 V (vs. standard hydrogen electrode (SHE)). The same group further applied the Pd83Cu17 bimetallic aerogels on carbon paper as electrode and [Bmim]BF4 aqueous solution (25 mol% [Bmim]BF4 and 75 mol% water) as electrolyte, the FE of eCO2RR for MeOH production reached 80.0% at −2.1 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) [61]. It was discovered that IL played a catalytic role in eCO2RR with the stabilization of *CO2 by [Bmim-CO2]+ which can form quickly through the hydrogen bonding interaction between CO2 and [Bmim]+ cation (Fig. 12 a) [148]. They proposed that this process may reduce the reaction barrierfor electron transfer to CO2, leading to the decrease of the overpotential of eCO2RR-to-MeOH. Iijima et al. further revealed the interaction between IL and electrode through potential-dependent and time-dependent in situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) [149]. It was discovered that the cationic head groups retain the imidazole molecules and induced formation of hydrogen bonds between adjacent imidazole molecules. These interactions between the imidazole molecules contributed to the release of protons from the imidazole molecules and the cationic head groups of IL would be attracted and tilted toward the negatively charged electrode surface at negative potentials which resulted in the selectivity towards MeOH (Fig. 12c and d). However, alcohols are liquid products which make it a great challenge to separate alcohols from IL reaction mixture, limiting the practical applications of IL in eCO2RR-to-alcohol process. Yang et al. applied Cu2− x Se(y) electrode in [Bmim]PF6 (30 wt%)/CH3CN/H2O (5 wt%) ternary electrolyte for eCO2RR-to-MeOH (Fig. 12b) [58]. It was found that the boiling point of [Bmim]PF6 is much higher than that of CH3OH, CH3CN and H2O, therefore the IL in the system could be separated via distillation. This research paved a way to relieve the separation problem through the regulation of anion and cation species focusing on the melting point of organic compound. It was suggested that the C2+ alcohol pathways involving ‘carbene’ intermediates were suppressed in IL by forming stable imidazolium-carbene compound(s) [150]. Therefore, the studies on eCO2RR-to-alcohol using ILs as electrolyte were rare and mostly were limited to C1 alcohol productions. Although ILs were effective for modifying the electrode and stabilizing *CO2, the intrinsic high viscosity, high price, and the separation problem still remain big challenges for their practical applications. Screening organic molecules with suitable cations and anions is expected to solve the challenge of eCO2RR-to-alcohol in IL electrolyte. Inspired by the solid-state batteries chemistry, solid-electrolyte reactors for eCO2RR to produce electrolyte-free liquid products were developed and proved to be highly effective in producing high-purity liquid-fuel solutions, such as 30 wt% pure formic acid solution [41,151]. However, the solid-electrolyte reactors for eCO2RR-to-alcohols are limited which deserved further investigations for achieving the high-purity and high-concentration alcohol productions by eCO2RR. 5 Advanced spectroelectrochemical analysis In situ (or operando) optical, X-ray and electron-based techniques can be used as a strong support for theoretical and experiment results to further reveal the mechanism of eCO2RR-to-alcohol (especially the C2+ alcohols) and identify the real active sites through the combination of optical and electrochemical techniques [152]. There has been a number of recent in situ (or operando) spectroscopy studies based on of the eCO2RR, including the (surface-enhanced) infrared adsorption spectroscopy ((SE)IRAS) or surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) [27,153,154]. As electrocatalytic eCO2RR typically involves submerged electrode surfaces, the attenuated total reflection (ATR-IR) operating mode is generally applied to minimize the electrolyte layer interference [122,155]. Yang et al. carried out in-situ ATR-IR at various applied potentials to detect the signals of important intermediates (*CO, *CHO, *OCH3, *COOH and *OH) during eCO2RR-to-MeOH process which provide experimental evidence for the reaction mechanism of eCO2RR-to-MeOH [122]. With the presence of a thin metallic layer atop the reflecting crystal plane, the absorption signal could be greatly enhanced due to the surface enhancement effects. This technique is often referred to as SEIRAS [122,155]. ATR-SEIRAS is particularly sensitive to adsorbates containing C–O bonds due to their high IR absorption cross-section which is widely applied in eCO2RR for the identification of the common intermediate *CO [156–158]. Isotope labelling can be used to confirm the peak assignment in Raman spectroscopy, as the harmonic oscillator model can predict the shift in the mode’s frequency [135]. The combination of theoretical calculations, experimental results and advanced characterization analysis is benefit for the better understanding of the eCO2RR-to-alcohol mechanism and the identification of the active site, so as to provide guidance for the design of catalysts and interfaces in the future. Mechanism understanding. By combining fast ATR-SEIRAS analysis, isotopic labeling, and potential stepping techniques, the initial reactant of eCO2RR was identified by Zhu et al. which suggested that CO2 molecules in equilibrium with bicarbonate anions were the actual carbon source in eCO2RR process [156]. Although the accurate amount of CO2 in equilibrium with solution bicarbonate and the as-induced mass transport effect was unclear, this study provided valuable insight to the eCO2RR mechanism in alkaline H-cell type configurations which has attracted more research interests in the design of solid–liquid interfaces by electrolyte engineering. Considering the alcohols are oxygenate products, the solvent water also plays a critical role as a source of O atoms in the formation of alcohols through eCO2RR [135]. By carrying out reduction of C16O in H2 18O electrolyte on oriented Cu surfaces and quantifying the isotopic composition of the products using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry. It was found that majority of the EtOH, acetate, and PrOH were 18O enriched. In detail, the fraction of EtOH with 18O was around 66% while that for PrOH was around 72% which suggested that solvent water played a dominant role in alcohol formation by eCO2RR. Based on the full-solvent quantum mechanics (QM) calculations, Grotthuss chain ethynyl concerted hydrolysis (GECH) mechanism of eCO2RR-to-EtOH was firstly reported (Fig. 13 a). It was suggested that six water molecules were connected by a hydrogen-bonding network and (18O) EtOH was resulted from solvent-based concerted hydrolysis by *C–CH to form *CH–CH(OH), in which the added H and OH are derived from waters at the opposite ends of a six-molecule Grotthuss chain. This study modified the mechanism of eCO2RR-to-C2 alcohol with the assist of advanced characterization techniques, subsequent work by Chang et al. further examined the more complicated C3 product pathways for PrOH [159]. On the basis that acetaldehyde (AcH) was an intermediate for EtOH and PrOH production from the CORR through C–C coupling between CO and AcH, Chang et al. used 13CO and perdeuterated AcH to reveal the PrOH formation mechanism. Combined with the quantitative analysis and in situ SEIRAS, they demonstrated that the AcH was not the main intermediate to form PrOH through direct coupling with CO which accounted for a small fraction of PrOH (36%) produced via cross-coupling with AcH in the electrolyte. Instead, they proposed that the short-lived adsorbed methylcarbonyl was likely to be the critical intermediate which bifurcated the C2 and C3 pathways. Hydrogenation of methylcarbonyl led to AcH and EtOH products, while the coupling of AcH with CO, followed by hydrogenation, led to PrOH product. Therefore, the in situ optical and isotope labeling techniques play critical roles in understanding the mechanisms of alcohol production through eCO2RR. Active site identification. Operando (or in situ) SERS has also been used to determine the catalyst state on OD Cu and bimetallic catalysts for eCO2RR [35,154,156,160]. It appears that the surfaces of OD Cu catalysts are reduced at CO2RR-relevant potentials within a few minutes. Recently, differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) has provided rich information to understand reaction mechanisms for eCO2RR [42,159]. Coupling the DEMS with atomic force microscopy (AFM) to monitor the morphological evolution and quasi in situ XPS to reveal the electronic states changes, the direct evidence for increased eCO2RR-to-EtOH selectivity on the Cu2O with the coexistence of Cu(I) and Cu(0) species was provided [42]. For the bimetallic system, Sargent’s group used in situ SERS to investigate the energetic fingerprints of the binding sites on the Cu and Ag/Cu samples and revealed the origin of the enhanced eCO2RR-to-EtOH selectivity (Fig. 13b–d) [35]. The excellent agreement between the simulated and experimental Raman spectra proved that the coordinated pure Cu surface was replaced with Cu neighboring Ag atoms in Ag/Cu catalysts, leading to the multiple different binding configurations and the distinct Raman peaks. Due to the unsaturated nature of the ethylene reaction intermediates, the ethylene reaction pathway was suppressed while EtOH production from the Ag/Cu catalyst with binding site diversity was promoted. electrochemical real-time mass spectrometry (EC-RTMS) has been recently developed by Khanipour’s group as a supplementary tool for in situ spectroscopy to monitor electrochemical reaction products in real time which tracked the enhanced formation of C2+ products over C1 products directly after Cu anodization, with unprecedented temporal resolution [161]. The hyphenation of in situ spectroscopy with online product identification techniques would be a next instrumental challenge in furthering understanding of eCO2RR-to-alcohols, as it would enable the establishment of direct relationships between observed adsorbed intermediates and product selectivity.
