Therefore, comprehensive studies based on the combination of DFT calculations, electrochemical data and spectroscopic evidence are desired in the following aspects: (a) understanding the eCO2RR-to-alcohol pathways; (b) identification of active species and (c) monitoring the catalyst state. 6 Challenges and perspectives for eCO2RR to alcohols In summary, eCO2RR provides a promising strategy to produce alcohols as high value-added chemicals/fuels, which hold great potential to fulfill the carbon–neutral goal. Although great progresses in the activity, selectivity and stability of electrocatalysts for CO2RR to alcohols have been achieved in recent years, applying them directly for practical industrial applications still remains a big challenge. In order to extend the laboratory research to industrial application, several key problems need to be further addressed as summarized below: (1) Low alcohol yield. Commercially viable eCO2RR catalysts need to reach an FE higher than 90% with a partial current density larger than 200 mA cm−2. However, the FEs of the reported electrocatalysts toward alcohol productions from eCO2RR are below the value as illustrated in Table 3. Although the high FEs of total C2+ products have been successfully achieved through the development of advanced electrocatalysts, the selectivity to specific C2+ alcohols still remain relatively low, especially for C3 alcohols. The product distributions of EtOH/C2 were below 60% while for PrOH/C2+ were under 5%–10%, resulting in a low yield of alcohol products. Considering the relatively high performance of Cu-based electrocatalysts in the production of C2+ alcohols, more attention should be paid to elucidating the possible mechanism of the exclusively alcohol production based on Cu catalysts. Through the combination of theoretical analysis and electrochemical characterizations, rational catalyst and interface design can be guided and achieved to activate the intrinsic reactivity of each active site and maximum its utilization. (2) Insufficient catalyst stability/durability. The long-term durability of most developed electrocatalysts toward alcohol productions remains a big challenge and the key factors for deactivation are still controversial. On the one hand, the active electrode/catalyst surface can be covered by the reaction intermediates and by-products, blocking and poisoning the catalyst’s active sites and leading to rapid catalytic activity degradation. On the other hand, the surface morphology reconstruction observed during electrolysis has proven to facilitate the catalytic process. Therefore, more investigations in the evolution of electrocatalysts during long-term eCO2RR process is crucial to reaveal the reasons beyond deactivation, so as to guide the durable catalyst design. (3) Low reactant concentration and product purity. The low solubility of CO2 in electrolytes results in slow mass transportations, resulting in relatively low current densities for CO2RR. Rational design of gas diffusion electrode and modification of the gas-liquid–solid interface are regarded as promising routes to achieve high current densities by increasing the local CO2 concentration. The large current densities of >300 mA cm−2 have been achieved for EtOH productions with the aid of GDE. However, the decrease of CO2 solubility with increasing total salt concentration under high current densities as a phenomenon known as the ‘salting-out’ effect and the evaporation of volatile alcohol products in high-CO2 rate electrocatalysis system need to be further addressed. One promising but challenging direction is to design novel catalytic reactors, such as solid-electrolyte reactors, that can produce high-purity and high-concentration liquid fuels directly without the need for downstream product-separation processes which has been achieved for HCOOH productions but rare for alcohol products. This review article aimes to provide a systematic guidance and inspire more researchers to develop innovative electrocatalysts for eCO2RR system towards alcohol productions. Ultimately, keeping innovative strategies in mind, it is expected that the performance and superiorities of the eCO2RR system will be further improved, including achieving an industrial-grade current density, high energy efficiency, and appreciable alcohol selectivity in the future to contribute to the creation of a carbon–neutral cycle. Lingxi Zhou is currently a PhD student at the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University under the supervision of Prof. Ruitao Lv. She received her B.S. degree from Sichuan Normal University in 2020. Her research interests include the rational design and synthesis of efficient electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction and electrochemical CO2 reduction. Ruitao Lv is currently a tenured Associate Professor at the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University. He received his Ph.D degree in 2009 from Tsinghua University. He has been a visiting scholar in Kyushu University (Japan) and a postdoctoral researcher in the Pennsylvania State University (USA). He joined Tsinghua University as a faculty member since 2013. His research interests include the defect engineering of low-dimensional materials for clean energy storage/conversion, electrocatalysis, molecular sensing.

coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical CO2 reduction (eCO2RR) is an emerging strategy to address the global carbon balance issues and fulfill the carbon-neutral goal through converting CO2 to value-added chemicals/fuels driven by renewable energy sources. The production of highly reduced carbon compounds beyond CO and formate, especially oxygenate alcohol products with high energy densities and large global market capacities, is particularly desirable for practical applications. However, the building of alcohol-selective eCO2RR electrocatalysis systems to overcome the high overpotential and poor durability remains a big challenge. Recently, diverse strategies have been developed for rational catalyst design towards alcohol productions from eCO2RR on the basis of the corresponding reaction mechanisms. In this review article, we firstly highlight recent advances in fundamental understanding of mechanisms in three electrochemical CO2-alcohol reaction pathways. Then, the design strategies focused on catalyst and interface design are summarized for building alcohol-selective eCO2RR electrocatalysis systems. The advanced characterization techniques are also discussed to provide more insights into eCO2RR-to-alcohols processes. Finally, the remaining challenges and perspectives for promoting eCO2RR to alcohols are proposed.
